questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas. During embryogenesis, the developing pancreatic ducts usually fuse in such a way that most of the 
dorsal duct drains into the proximal part of the ventral duct. The proximal portion of the dorsal 
duct usually persists as an accessory duct. In about 10% of the population, there is a failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic 
buds leading to a condition called pancreatic divisum (pancreas divisum). Pancreatic drainage is 
accomplished mainly through the accessory papilla. Since most of the pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, the pancreas 
divisum can lead to a partial obstruction due to the small minor papilla, leading to the 
development of relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of pancreatic divisum?

options.b: Pancreatojejunostomy is also known as Puestow's procedure
options.d: ERCP is more advantageous than MRCP for the diagnosis

questions.explanation:
MRCP is more advantageous than ERCP in diagnosing pancreatic divisum. This is because, 
MRCP can delineate the entire dorsal pancreatic duct, whereas ERCP can assess only the ventral 
duct on cannulation of the major duodenal papilla. The diagnosis of pancreatic divisum can also be made by EUS, or ERCP, augmented by injection 
of secretin if necessary. Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stenting of the minor papilla relieve the symptoms. Surgical 
intervention may involve sphincteroplasty, pancreatojejunostomy (Puestow procedure), or even 
resection of the pancreatic head. The image given below shows an MRCP done for a case of pancreatic divisum. 817 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A 9-year-old girl was referred to the OPD with a chronic history of early satiety and recurrent 
non-bilious vomiting after heavy meals. Barium meal revealed a diffusely narrowed second 
portion of the duodenum, suggesting extrinsic compression. Which of the following 
statements is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

options.a: It is associated with failure of complete rotation of the ventral bud
options.b: Can be associated with classic double bubble sign on radiograph
options.c: Duodenoduodenostomy is the treatment of choice
options.d: MRCP is the gold standard investigation

questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmental 
anomaly leading to duodenal compression. Laparotomy with a thorough gross examination of the 
duodenum and the head of the pancreas is the gold standard test for an annular pancreas, not an 
MRCP. The annular pancreas is due to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral 
pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third 
part of the duodenum. It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, more 
prevalent in children with Down’s syndrome. 818 
Sold by @itachibot Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates. Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it is 
non-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CT 
scan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing AP 
remains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the 
head of the pancreas. The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).

questions.question:
Question 4: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with sudden onset abdominal pain in the epigastric 
region radiating to the back. The pain relieves on leaning forwards. X-ray abdomen shows no 809 
Sold by @itachibot gas under the diaphragm. Elevated amylase levels and total WBC count are seen. Which of 
the following signs are likely to be present in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Rovsing sign and Aaron sign are seen in 
acute appendicitis. Rovsing sign: Pain in the right lower quadrant during palpation of the left lower quadrant. Aaron sign: Pain or pressure in the epigastrium or anterior chest with firm pressure applied to 
McBurney’s point. In severe acute pancreatitis, the injured pancreas releases pancreatic enzymes that cause fat 
necrosis and inflammation, occasionally resulting in peri-pancreatic bleeding. The resulting fluid 
collection can travel via an anatomical defect of the transversalis fascia. This accumulates at 
various sites and shows discoloration of the skin. Cullen's sign: If the blood diffuses from the retroperitoneum along with the gastrohepatic and 
falciform ligaments to the umbilicus, it results in bluish discoloration around the umbilicus Grey Turner sign: If the blood diffuses from the posterior pararenal space to the lateral edge of the 
quadratus lumborum muscle, it results in bluish discoloration of the flanks Fox sign: Pooling of retroperitoneal hemorrhage at the inguinal ligament shows 
discoloration below the inguinal ligament Bryant sign: Pooling of blood at the scrotum

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of acute pancreatitis is the presence of gallstones (50-70%). The second 
most common cause is alcohol abuse (25%). Causes of acute pancreatitis: (Mnemonic: I GET SMASHED) • I – Idiopathic • G – Gallstones • E – Ethanol • T – Trauma • S – Steroids • M – Mumps, malignancy (pancreatic cancer) 819 
Sold by @itachibot • A – Autoimmune • S – Scorpion sting • H – Hypercalcemia, hypertriglyceridemia (Usually more than 1000 mg/dL) • E – Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) • D – Drugs

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient presenting with acute abdomen was found to have elevated serum amylase levels. 
Which of the following should be part of your differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
All the above conditions should be part of the differential diagnosis in patients with acute 
abdominal pain and elevated serum amylase levels. Conditions associated with elevated serum amylase levels: • Burns • Pregnancy • Pancreatitis • Cholecystitis • Diabetic ketoacidosis • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy • Aortic aneurysm • Renal failure • Renal transplantation • Chronic liver disease • Intestinal obstruction • Drugs like morphine • Salivary gland involvement: mumps, calculus, maxillofacial surgery • Tumors of the lungs, esophagus, breast, or ovary (LEBO)

questions.question: Question 7: All of the following derangements can be expected in a patient with acute pancreatitis except:
questions.explanation:
Acute pancreatitis causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. The pancreatic enzymes cause autodigestion of the mesenteric fat leading to the release of free 
fatty acids. These free fatty acids combine with calcium to form calcium salts, causing low levels of 
circulating calcium. Hypercalcemia may cause acute pancreatitis. Hypocalcemia is a complication of acute 
pancreatitis. 820 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: 810 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is not used to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.explanation: Alvarado scoring is used in acute appendicitis, not acute pancreatitis.

questions.question:
Question 9: All of the following parameters will be included in the assessment of acute pancreatitis using 
Ranson's criteria, except:
questions.explanation: Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) > 350 IU/L is included in Ranson’s criteria, not 250 IU/L.

questions.question: Question 10: Revised atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of:
questions.explanation: Revised atlanta classification is used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis. Revised atlanta classification: Mild Acute Pancreatitis • No organ failure • No local or systemic complications Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis • Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or • Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure Severe Acute Pancreatitis • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours) – Single organ or multiorgan

questions.question: Question 11: A gasless abdomen is seen in:
questions.explanation:
A gasless abdomen is an X-ray feature that can be seen in acute pancreatitis. Patients with acute 
pancreatitis can have significant vomiting and diarrhea that may produce a gasless abdomen. Common causes of gasless abdomen include: • High obstruction: gastric outlet obstruction, congenital atresia • Small bowel obstruction • Bowel ischemia • Ascites • Acute pancreatitis • Gastroenteritis • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement • Post-surgery following total colectomy, esophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy, and low anterior 
resection 821 
Sold by @itachibot • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults Note: In intussusception, an X-ray shows small bowel obstruction, a mass, and a paucity of gas in 
the right iliac fossa.

questions.question:
Question 12: 811 
Sold by @itachibot A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal 
pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back 
and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is 
given below. What is the sign that is seen in the radiograph?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the colon cut-off sign, which is seen in acute pancreatitis. The colon cut-off sign refers to the abrupt termination of the gas filling of the colon on the left 
side. The inflammation of acute pancreatitis may extend to the phrenicocolic ligament via the 
transverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure resulting in the colon 
cut-off sign. All the other options mentioned above are also seen in acute pancreatitis.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following statements is false regarding usage of the contrast-enhanced CT scan 
in cases of acute pancreatitis?

options.a: It is the investigation of choice
options.b: It should be done within 72 hours from the onset of symptoms
options.c: Balthazar criteria is used to stage the severity of pancreatitis detected on CT scan
options.d: Signs of sepsis is an indication for CT scan

questions.explanation:
The optimal time for performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acute pancreatitis 
is more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate 
the extent of necrosis. A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice in acute pancreatitis. However, it is not 
performed in all cases of pancreatitis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis: • Diagnostic uncertainty • In patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis • In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration • When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or a 
pseudoaneurysm The image below is a CT scan from a patient with acute exudative pancreatitis. 822 
Sold by @itachibot The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT scan is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient with acute pancreatitis underwent a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. CT 
scan shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas without necrosis. What will be the CT 
severity index of the patient? 812 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The CT severity index (CTSI) of this patient will be 1. The CT severity index for grading of acute pancreatitis is determined as the sum of two scores: • Balthazar score: grading of pancreatitis • Necrosis score: grading of the extent of pancreatic necrosis The Balthazar score for diffuse enlargement of the pancreas is 1. Since there is no necrosis, the 
necrosis score of the patient is zero. Hence the CTSI of this patient is 1.

questions.question: Question 15: When will you use the SOFA score in a patient with acute pancreatitis?

options.b: To assess the need for surgery
options.c: In cases of pancreatic abscess formation
options.d: To assess the length of hospital stay

questions.explanation:
The Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score is used to assess organ failure in acute 
pancreatitis. The three organ systems most frequently involved are the cardiovascular, 
respiratory, and renal systems. Multiple organ failures are said to exist when 2 or more organs 
register 2 or more points on these scoring systems. qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection 
who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU). It uses three 
criteria, assigning one point each for • Low blood pressure (SBP100 mmHg) • High respiratory rate ( 22 breaths per min) • Altered mentation (Glasgow coma scale, <15) 823 
Sold by @itachibot The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt 
to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 35-year-old man presented with a 1-day history of sudden onset of severe abdominal pain 
with radiation to the back. He gives a history of binge drinking on the night prior to his 
symptom onset. He is hemodynamically stable and there is no sign of organ impairment. His 
serum amylase level is 500 U/L ( normal: 23–85 U/L) and lipase level is 1100 U/L (normal: 
10-140 U/L). Which of the following is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

options.a: CECT abdomen is almost always necessary to establish the diagnosis
options.b: CT should be performed 72 hours after the onset of symptoms to assess complications
options.c: Modified marshall scoring system can be used to assess the severity of organ failure
options.d: Early initiation of enteral nutrition is beneficial for overall improvement of prognosis

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with characteristic lab findings is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. 
CECT abdomen is not always necessary to diagnose acute pancreatitis. According to the revised Atlanta classification, acute pancreatitis is clinically defined by at least 
the first two of three features: • abdominal pain suggestive of pancreatitis (epigastric pain often radiating to the back), • serum amylase and lipase levels  3 times normal (imaging is to be used if the elevated values 
are less than 3 times normal); and • characteristic imaging findings on CT, magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, or transabdominal 
ultrasonographic (US) studies. If acute pancreatitis is diagnosed on the basis of the first two criteria with no systemic sign of 
severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome or persistent organ failure, contrast material–
enhanced CT may not be necessary for determining patient care. Option B: The optimal time for performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acute 
pancreatitis is more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT may 
underestimate the extent of necrosis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis are • Diagnostic uncertainty • In patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis • In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration • When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or a 
pseudoaneurysm Option C: For severe acute pancreatitis with systemic inflammatory response syndrome and 
possible organ impairment, the modified marshall scoring can be used to assess the severity of 
organ failure. It includes respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal systems scores. A score of more 
than 2 for any organs indicates organ failure. Revised Atlanta classification recommends the 
modified Marshall scoring system as the main tool in determining organ failure. Option D: Current evidence confirms that the administration of enteral nutrition is beneficial for 
the treatment of severe acute pancreatitis. Enteral feeding reduces mortality, infectious 
complications, and multiorgan failure. In terms of the timing of enteral nutritional support, 
relatively early administration within 48 or 72 h of hospital admission is suggested.

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with pancreatitis is likely to develop all of the following vascular complications, 
except:
questions.explanation:
Mesenteric artery thrombosis is unlikely in patients with acute pancreatitis. The most common vascular complication following acute pancreatitis is arterial pseudoaneurysm. 824 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A chronic alcoholic presented with complaints of progressive abdominal distension. His past 
history is significant for acute pancreatitis which was managed by supportive care. USG 
abdomen showed peri-pancreatic ascitic fluid collection. A large volume paracentesis (LVP) 
was performed. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

options.a: The ascitic fluid will be low in protein.
options.b: Amylase levels in the fluid are raised.
options.c: Somatostatin will help in decreasing secretion.

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of pancreatic ascites. The pancreatic ascitic fluid is rich in 
enzymes, and not low in protein. Pancreatic ascites occurs due to the disruption of the pancreatic duct. It presents with significant 
abdominal distention, with free intra-abdominal fluid. Diagnostic paracentesis typically demonstrates turbid fluid with elevated amylase and lipase 
levels. Treatment involves suppression of pancreatic secretion by parenteral or nasojejunal feeding and 
administration of octreotide/somatostatin. Abdominal drainage combined with the endoscopic 
placement of a pancreatic stent across the disruption is done. If the above steps fail, surgical treatment consisting of distal pancreatic resection and closure of 
the proximal stump is done.

questions.question:
Question 19: A young lady presents with acute epigastric pain and vomiting. She also gives a history of 
pain and swelling over the right parotid gland for 3 days. USG abdomen reveals 
peripancreatic ascitic fluid collection. Which of the following is not true about the fluid 
collection?

options.a: It is not associated with fibrous wall
options.b: The most common vessel involved is the splenic artery

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis caused due to mumps. Hemosuccus 
pancreaticus in acute pancreatitis is not associated with ascites. Hemosuccus pancreaticus is due to the erosion of the wall of the pancreatic pseudocyst into the 
splenic artery forming a direct communication. It presents with abdominal pain and upper 
gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, without ascites. In contrast to pseudocysts and cystic neoplasias of the pancreas, fluid collections are not 
surrounded or encased by epithelium or fibrotic capsules. Diagnostic paracentesis typically demonstrates turbid fluid with elevated amylase and lipase 
levels. Most fluid collections will be spontaneously reabsorbed by the peritoneum. Treatment 
involves suppression of pancreatic secretion by parenteral or nasojejunal feeding and 
administration of octreotide/somatostatin. Abdominal drainage combined with the endoscopic 
placement of a pancreatic stent across the disruption is done. If the above steps fail, surgical treatment consisting of distal pancreatic resection and closure of 
the proximal stump is done.

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted following binge drinking. 7-days 
post-admission, he complains of fever with chills and rigor. Blood investigation shows a WBC 
count of 21,450. CT scan reveals the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic tissue. 
How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a history of pancreatitis, elevated WBC, and CT scan findings are 
suggestive of pancreatic abscess. It is treated by percutaneous drainage. A pancreatic abscess is a circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus, usually in proximity to 
the pancreas. It may be an acute fluid collection or walled-off necrosis that has become infected. 825 
Sold by @itachibot Clinical features include: • Fever with chills • Elevated white blood cell count • Abdominal pain Contrast-enhanced CT scan and MRI are both options for the assessment of pancreatic necrosis 
and abscesses. On imaging, the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic and/or 
peripancreatic tissues is consistent with an underlying infection. Treatment is by percutaneous drainage with the widest possible drains placed under imaging 
guidance, along with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.

questions.question:
Question 21: 814 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following will not be part of the management plan of patients with infected 
pancreatic necrosis?
questions.explanation:
Infected pancreatic necrosis should not be managed conservatively with antibiotics alone because 
of the high risk of multiorgan failure and death. CT scan has to be performed in patients with severe acute pancreatitis, organ failure, sepsis, and 
in patients with clinical deterioration despite the treatment: • If the CT scan shows the presence of sterile pancreatic necrosis medical management is 
recommended. • If the CT scan shows the presence of necrosis with evidence of infection, then ultrasound or 
CT-guided aspiration of the fluid has to be done and the fluid is sent for staining and culture. Infected pancreatic necrosis is treated by the administration of intravenous antibiotics (preferably 
carbapenems) and percutaneous drainage of the infected fluid. Pancreatic necrosectomy is be 
considered in the patients if the clinical condition worsens despite percutaneous drainage.

questions.question:
Question 22: Regarding the revised Atlanta classification for morphologic stages of acute pancreatitis, 
which of the following is not true?

options.a: Acute necrotic collection is non-encapsulated necrosis within 4 weeks of onset
options.b: Acute peripancreatic fluid collection can be seen in interstitial edematous pancreatitis
options.c: Pancreatic pseudocyst can be seen in necrotizing pancreatitis
options.d: Collection that contains non-liquefied material is more likely to become infected

questions.explanation:
Pancreatic pseudocyst is seen as a sequela of interstitial edematous pancreatitis, which is a 
non-necrotic collection. Necrotizing pancreatitis usually leads to acute necrotic collection (ANC) 
and walled-off necrosis (on encapsulation of ANC). Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid and their collections can be 
classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation. • IEP - Interstitial Edematous Pancreatitis • APFC - Acute Peripancreatic Fluid Collection: Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks • Pancreatic pseudocyst: Non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks) • Necrotising Pancreatitis 826 
Sold by @itachibot • ANC - Acute Necrotic Collection: Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks • WON - Walled-Off Necrosis: Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks) ANC, APFC, WON, and pancreatic pseudocysts can be infected or non-infected. questions.question:
Question 23: A 12-year-old girl was rushed to the casualty after she was injured by a bicycle’s handlebar in 
the abdomen. She complains of severe epigastric pain. On examination, bruises are seen in 
the epigastrium. Her CT scan is given below. Which of the following statements is false about 
her condition? 815 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with a handlebar injury and the CT scan showing transection of the 
body of the pancreas are suggestive pancreatic injury. Plasma amylase levels are not sensitive in 
pancreatic injuries. The most common mechanism of pancreatic injury in children is blunt trauma (because of the 
decreased amount of fat and incomplete protection of the rib cage). In adults, penetrating injuries 
are the most common cause. Involvement of other organs is also likely to be seen. Direct compression of the epigastrium against the vertebral column and a blunt object (handlebar) 
is typically seen after bicycle injuries. The most common segment of the pancreas affected is the 
body. Patients usually present with epigastric pain. In some cases, a delayed presentation may be due to 
leakage of pancreatic fluids. The modality of choice is the CT scan of the abdomen. If there is doubt about duct disruption, an 
urgent ERCP or MRCP should be done. Surgery is indicated if the main pancreatic duct is disrupted. A damage control procedure with 
packing and drainage should be performed initially and the patient referred for definitive surgery 
after stabilization. Definitive management includes: • Distal pancreatectomy - If the body or tail is involved • External drainage - If the head of the pancreas is involved • Pancreatoduodenectomy - If the pancreatic head and duodenum is involved 827 
Sold by @itachibot Chronic Pancreatitis
